headline: Stock Market Today: Dow Ekes Out Gain; Nasdaq Comes Off Lows While Palantir Retakes Key Level After 15% Plunge
summary: Other major indexes remained in the red in a session where investors saw division amongst monetary policymakers in the minutes of the Federal Reserve's July meeting.  Several retail stocks moved on earnings, while Palantir Technologies managed to retake a key level on the stock market today after falling more than 15%.  Meanwhile, investors awaited a speech from Fed Chairman Jerome Powell.

Meanwhile, investors awaited a speech from Fed Chairman Jerome Powell.

headline: Nasdaq, S&P 500 close lower with tech stocks leading the sell-off
summary: The Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) closed about 142 points lower on Wednesday, as Big Tech names like Apple (AAPL), Micron (MU), and Intel (INTC) weighed on the index. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) also closed in the red, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) posted a slight gain. Yahoo Finance Markets and Data Editor Jared Blikre recaps the action at the close. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

headline: Noodles, GoodRx, Micron, Custom Truck One Source, and CarMax Shares Are Falling, What You Need To Know
summary: A number of stocks fell in the afternoon session after the major indices continued to pull back, with technology stocks accounting for most of the market's largest decliners. A key reason for this trend is that much of the recent market gains were concentrated in the "AI trade," which includes these large technology and semiconductor companies. So this could also mean that some investors are locking in some gains ahead of more definitive feedback from the Fed.

headline: Stock Market Today: Dow Falls As Nasdaq Breaks Key Level Before Fed Minutes; Palantir Dives (Live Coverage)
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and other major stock indexes were driving further into the red Wednesday morning.  The Nasdaq fell below a key level as Wall Street awaited minutes from the Federal Reserve's latest policy meeting.  Meanwhile, retail stocks moved on earnings, and artificial intelligence software maker Palantir Technologies was stretching a losing streak into a sixth consecutive session on the stock market today.

headline: Tech Selling Picks Up Again. Nasdaq Slides for Second Straight Day.
summary: The Nasdaq Composite fell 1.4% on Wednesday after it dropped 1.5% yesterday.  The Nasdaq is on track to fall at least 1% for second day in a row for the first time since April 4, when it fell 5.97% and 5.82%, respectively, according to Dow Jones Market Data.  Market breadth is still solid, with nearly 300 S&P 500 stocks set to close higher, but Palantir Technologies continued to struggle.

headline: Tech stocks pressure Wall St as caution sets in ahead of Fed meet
summary: After driving much of the market's recovery from the April selloff, tech stocks are pulling back as investors reassess high valuations in the sector.  Deepening concerns of government interference with companies, sources said the Trump administration was looking into taking equity stakes in chip companies such as Intel in exchange for grants under the CHIPS Act - just weeks after unprecedented revenue-sharing deals with Nvidia and AMD.  Nvidia slid 2.8% and Advanced Micro Devices lost 3%, while Intel and Micron fell about 6% each.

raw.headline: Tech stocks pressure Wall St as caution sets in ahead of Fed meet

Nvidia slid 2.8% and Advanced Micro Devices lost 3%, while Intel and Micron fell about 6% each.

headline: US eyes stake in Intel, maybe other chipmakers too: sources
summary: STORY: The U.S. has confirmed it could invest in Intel, but government involvement in the sector might not stop there.Speaking Tuesday, White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt said Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick was in talks for a 10% stake in the troubled chipmaker:“And it's a creative idea that has never been done before, to ensure that we're both reshoring these critical supply chains while also gaining something of it for the American taxpayer.”However, Reuters sources say the administration is looking into taking stakes in other chipmakers too.That’s focused on firms that took money under the so-called CHIPS Act, which provided funding to build factories in the country.Besides Intel, that would mean U.S. memory chip maker Micron.Taiwan’s TSMC also got funds under the act, as did South Korea’s Samsung.None of those firms commented on the Reuters report, and neither did the White House.Lutnick has previously said that Washington does not want to tell companies how to run their businesses.But any investment in Intel or others would be unprecedented for the sector.In the past, the government has only invested in companies to provide support during times of economic turmoil.It’s not entirely unprecedented for Trump, however.Earlier this year, he approved Nippon Steel’s takeover of U.S. Steel after being promised a “golden share” that would give Washington significant influence.
